abstracts.cdata!:
This brief on primary school education
            in India spells out that the nineties witnessed remarkable
            progress in education indicators in India. Between 1992/93
            and 1998/99, net enrollment of the group of children aged
            six to eight years increased from 68 percent to 82 percent
            across the country. In rural areas, the net enrollment of
            girls jumped from 55 percent to 76 percent, while that of
            children as a whole increased from 72 percent to 84 percent.
            Despite theseachievements, about 39 million children, or
            about 21 percent of the group of six to 14 years, were the
            school completion rate and the 5th grade was below the 78
            percent national levelin 1999 and 2000. Large disparities
            were common in all states and districts. Among other
            activities, the government program funded by the innovative
            initiatives were designed to encourage the attendance of
            children to school, pay for more teachers,  give free
            textbooks for girls and disadvantaged students, provide
            teaching and learning materials, establishment of local
            institutions to support schools and teachers, as well as
            monitoring and evaluation. Several reports indicate that
            quality improvement remains a challenge to be faced.
